questions.text: You are attending an operation to remove a thymic tumor from the superior mediastinum. The surgeon asks, "What important nerve lying on and partly curving posteriorly around the arch of the aorta should we be careful of as we remove this mass?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The left vagus nerve gives off the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, which loops under the arch of the aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum, making it vulnerable during surgeries involving the superior mediastinum (Option C is correct)
  • The left phrenic nerve passes anterior to the root of the lung and is not in close relation to the aortic arch loop (Option A ruled out)
  • The left sympathetic trunk runs along the vertebral column and is located posteriorly, not closely related to the aortic arch (Option B ruled out)
  • The right phrenic nerve is on the right side of the heart and has no relation to the left-sided aortic arch, so is irrelevant here (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Left vagus nerve and its recurrent laryngeal branch are at risk during superior mediastinal surgeries
  • Damage may result in hoarseness due to vocal cord paralysis

questions.text: A 23-year-old male injured in an industrial explosion was found to have multiple small metal fragments in his thoracic cavity. Since the pericardium was torn inferiorly, the surgeon began to explore for fragments in the pericardial sac. Slipping her hand under the heart apex, she slid her fingers upward and to the right within the sac until they were stopped by the cul-de-sac formed by the pericardial reflection near the base of the heart. Her fingertips were then in the:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The oblique pericardial sinus is a cul-de-sac formed by the reflection of serous pericardium near the base of the heart, located behind the left atrium, bounded by the pulmonary veins and IVC.
  • The coronary sinus is a venous structure in the posterior part of the coronary sulcus, not a space where a hand could be inserted (Option A ruled out)
  • The coronary sulcus is a groove on the heart's surface for coronary vessels, not a pericardial space (Option B ruled out)
  • The costomediastinal recess is part of the pleural cavity, not the pericardial sac (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The oblique sinus is a blind pericardial recess behind the left atrium
  • Important to recognize in cardiac surgery and pericardial tamponade drainage

questions.text: In cardiac surgery, it is sometimes necessary to clamp off all arterial flow out of the heart. This can be done within the pericardial sac by inserting the index finger immediately behind the two great arteries and compressing them with the thumb of the same hand. The index finger would have to be inserted into which space?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The transverse pericardial sinus lies posterior to the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk, and anterior to the superior vena cava
  • In cardiac surgery, the index finger can be passed through this sinus to isolate and clamp the great arteries, controlling arterial outflow.
  • Label A corresponds to the superior vena cava, not a pericardial sinus (Option A ruled out)
  • Label C corresponds to the left atrium or pulmonary veins region, which relates to the oblique sinus, not involved in arterial clamping (Option C ruled out)
  • Label D is too inferior and does not correspond to a pericardial sinus involved in this maneuver (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Transverse sinus is the space used to clamp aorta and pulmonary trunk
  • Surgical landmark: lies between arterial and venous ends of the heart

questions.text: Which structure contains postganglionic sympathetic fibers?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The ulnar nerve is a mixed peripheral nerve that carries postganglionic sympathetic fibers to structures like sweat glands, blood vessels, and arrector pili muscles in the skin.
  • The greater thoracic splanchnic nerve carries preganglionic sympathetic fibers to abdominal ganglia (Option A ruled out)
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus and carries somatic motor and sensory fibers, not sympathetic fibers (Option B ruled out)
  • The sympathetic trunk contains preganglionic and postganglionic sympathetic fibers, but it is not a structure that directly distributes postganglionic fibers to effectors (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Postganglionic sympathetic fibers reach skin and extremities via spinal nerves like the ulnar nerve
  • Greater splanchnic nerves carry preganglionic fibers
  • Know the distinction between sympathetic ganglia, trunks, and peripheral nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles seen below does not attach to the first rib?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Label A represents the anterior scalene, which attaches to the first rib (Option B ruled out)
  • Label B represents the subclavius, which inserts onto the first rib and costal cartilage (Option A ruled out)
  • Label D shows the middle scalene, which also inserts onto the first rib (Option C ruled out)
  • Label C corresponds to the levator scapulae, which inserts on the superior angle of the scapula and has no attachment to the first rib (Option D is correct)

Key Takeaways:

  • Muscles attaching to the first rib include anterior scalene, middle scalene, and subclavius
  • Levator scapulae attaches to the scapula, not the rib

questions.text: A patient who is chronic smoker presented with cough, chest pain, dyspnea, and right shoulder pain. Chest X-ray revealed homogeneous opacity at the lung apex and destruction of the first rib. Which of the following is not compressed?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The clinical scenario suggests a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor), commonly affecting structures at the lung apex, particularly on the right side
  • The thoracic duct ascends on the left side of the vertebral column and enters the venous system at the left venous angle, making it unlikely to be compressed by a right apical mass (Option B is correct)
  • The superior intercostal artery runs close to the apex of the lung and may be compressed (Option A ruled out)
  • The first posterior intercostal vein, located near the first rib and apex, is also at risk in a Pancoast tumor (Option C ruled out)
  • The sympathetic trunk, especially the stellate ganglion (T1), is in close proximity and often involved, leading to Horner's syndrome (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Pancoast tumors affect apical thoracic structures on the same side
  • The thoracic duct is spared in right-sided lesions due to its left-sided course.
